subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Unicode proposal again.
msgSnippet: It seems to me that unless the glyphs and sound of two characters are identical they are not the same letter. Also I didn t consider alternate glyph forms in
messageBody:
It seems to me that unless the glyphs and sound of two characters are
identical they are not the same letter.
Also I didn't consider alternate glyph forms in that list but they
should be taken into account since they alter the behaviour of a
character which is worse.

Michael Everson wrote:
>
> At 22:26 +0100 2007-05-28, amd64_hacker wrote:
> >Ah, oops - I didn't mean to respond privately, I guess I hit the wrong
> >button. :)
> >I'd be happy to re-post that message to the Unicode list if you like.
>
> Here is fine.
>
> >Okay, as I see it the following glyphs are the same in Quikscript and
> >Shavian:
>
> I am working on my own analysis, but it's not a glyph standard, it's
> a character standard. A lot of the differences between Quikscript and
> Shavian seem to me to be trivial. From my reading so far, complete
> changes in ductus appies to a very small set of characters. But I am
> still working on it.
>
> >DAY == DEAD
> >KEY == KICK
> >FEE == THIGH (different sound)
>
> I see a swap between think/the and for/of
>
> >SEE == SO
> >ZOO == ZOO
> >SHE == SURE
> >CHEER == CHURCH
> >JAY == JUDGE
> >WAY == WOE
> >ING == HUNG (different sound?)
>
> It's INK. No. The sound is "ng"
>
> >ROE == ROAR
> >IT == IF
> >ET == EGG
> >AT == ASH
> >AH == MIME (different sound)
> >AWE == NUN (different sound)
>
> Again, possibly this is an innovation on the part of QS, but remember
> Latin "c" is used for a great many sounds.
>
> >OX == ON
> >UTTER == ADO and LOLL (different sound)
> >OWE == OAK
> >
> >Please double check that list though - I have been hitting the wrong
> >buttons a lot today. :)
>
> I'm working on it. It's 01:17, and there is plenty of time.
>
> >
> >There are 13 glyphs/sounds pairs which match up (I'm not certain on
> >ING/HUNG).
> >Since code points are allocated in 16s we would still use the same space
> >but we would have more unused code points.
> >That would leave room for additions, but Quikscript is quite well
> >defined are we going to need them?
>
> I'll look at this more over the next while.
> --
> Michael Everson * http://www.evertype.com <http://www.evertype.com>
>
>

It seems to me that unless the glyphs and sound of two characters are
identical they are not the same letter.
Also I didn't consider alternate glyph forms in that list but they
should be taken into account since they alter the behaviour of a
character which is worse.
